4 Data visualisation: ggplot2 library("tidyverse") 4.1 Why visualise data? 4.1.1 The Anscombe’s Quartet In Anscombe, F. J. (1973). “Graphs in Statistical Analysis” there were the following dataset: quartet <- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/agricolamz/2020.02_Naumburg_R/master/data/anscombe.csv") quartet quartet %>% group_by(dataset) %>% summarise(mean_X = mean(x), mean_Y = mean(y), sd_X = sd(x), sd_Y = sd(y), cor = cor(x, y), n_obs = n()) %>% select(-dataset) %>% round(2) Lets visualise those datasets: 4.1.2 The DataSaurus In Matejka and Fitzmaurice (2017) “Same Stats, Different Graphs” there are the following datasets: datasaurus <- read_csv("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/agricolamz/2020.02_Naumburg_R/master/data/datasaurus.csv") datasaurus And… all discriptive statistics are the same! datasaurus %>% group_by(dataset) %>% summarise(mean_X = mean(x), mean_Y = mean(y), sd_X = sd(x), sd_Y = sd(y), cor = cor(x, y), n_obs = n()) %>% select(-dataset) %>% round(1) 4.2 Basic ggplot2 ggplot2 is a modern tool for data visualisation. There are a lot of extentions for ggplot2. There is also a cheatsheet on ggplot2
